text:
In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre.

Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties.

Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells.

Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation.

The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search.

The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change.

When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system.

The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change.

Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties.

Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search.

Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically.

In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions.

Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation.

Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms.

In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry.

Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles.

Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output.

A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs.

Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval.

Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output.

Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region.

Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways.

Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time.

Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants.

A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions.

Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output.

In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically.

Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible.

Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection.

Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes.

An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions.

When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change.

Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists.

Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms.

Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs.

In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time.

Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions.

Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms.

Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells.

Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles.

Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry.

Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there.

Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms.

When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells.

In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products.

Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection.

Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre.

The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour.

Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body.

The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour.

Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems.
