Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP.

Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached.

A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible.

Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain.

Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms.

Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles.

Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements.

Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity.

Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically.

Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms.

In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities.

Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically.

Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways.

Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically.

Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells.

In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes.

Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time.

Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output.

Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs.

The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment.

Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems.

Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity.

Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

Redox processes are analysed by assigning oxidation numbers and balancing the loss and gain of electrons. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties. The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. Equilibrium in a reversible reaction is described by an equilibrium constant that relates the activities of reactants and products. Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs.

Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles.

When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals.

In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases.

A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there.

Thermodynamic quantities such as enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy help predict whether a process is feasible. A chemical reaction involves rearrangement of atoms so that old bonds are broken and new bonds are formed between different atoms. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. The rate of a reaction depends on concentration, temperature, presence of catalyst and the physical state of reactants. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs. Intermolecular forces such as hydrogen bonding, dipole interactions and dispersion forces influence physical properties.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements.

The structure of a molecule is interpreted using ideas of hybridisation, bond angles and electron domain geometry. In aqueous solutions we frequently work with concepts like molarity, molality and mole fraction to express composition. Electrochemistry connects chemical change with electrical energy through galvanic cells and electrolytic cells. Acid base theories provide different ways of identifying species that donate or accept protons or electron pairs.

Continuity at a point requires that the limit of the function at that point equals the value of the function there. Integration is introduced as the inverse operation to differentiation and as a way to accumulate quantities. When studying limits we ask what value a function approaches as the input comes arbitrarily close to a given point. Basic differentiation rules allow us to compute derivatives of sums, products, quotients and compositions of functions. Sequences and series provide tools for approximating functions and for studying convergence behaviour. The derivative has a geometric interpretation as the slope of the tangent line to the graph of the function. The derivative of a function at a point is defined as the limit of the difference quotient whenever this limit exists. Techniques such as substitution and integration by parts help evaluate more complicated integrals. A function is a rule that assigns to each element of a domain exactly one element of a codomain. Definite integrals are connected to areas under curves when the integrand is non negative on a given interval.

Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached. Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions.

Ecological relationships describe how populations of different species interact with each other and with their physical environment. Cellular respiration is a multi step process that gradually releases energy from glucose to synthesise ATP. Cells are considered the basic structural and functional units of living organisms across all kingdoms of life. Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy using pigment systems located in chloroplast membranes. Homeostasis refers to the ability of an organism to maintain a relatively stable internal environment despite external change. Genetic information is stored in the sequence of nucleotides within DNA molecules housed inside the nucleus or nucleoid region. The plasma membrane regulates the movement of substances into and out of the cell using a variety of transport mechanisms. Evolution explains both the unity and diversity of life by proposing that species change over generations through natural selection. Enzymes act as biological catalysts by lowering the activation energy of biochemical reactions without being consumed. In multicellular organisms cells are organised into tissues, organs and organ systems that coordinate specific functions.

In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations.

Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles.

Arrays and linked lists are fundamental linear data structures that store collections of elements in different ways. An algorithm is a finite sequence of well defined instructions that transforms given input into desired output. In practice data structures and algorithms are chosen to balance speed, memory usage and implementation complexity. Time complexity provides a way to estimate how the running time of an algorithm grows as the size of the input increases. Stacks operate on a last in first out discipline while queues follow a first in first out ordering of elements. Trees are hierarchical structures made of nodes connected by edges with exactly one simple path between any two nodes. Hash tables provide average constant time performance for search, insert and delete operations under suitable assumptions. Graph algorithms often rely on traversal strategies such as depth first search and breadth first search. Sorting algorithms reorder elements in a collection so that they follow a specified comparison relation. Recursion allows a function to call itself on smaller instances of a problem until a base case is reached.

Free body diagrams are drawn to represent all the forces such as weight, normal reaction, tension and friction acting on the system. For one dimensional motion with constant acceleration we often use kinematic relations between displacement, velocity and time. Newton's laws are used as a starting point to connect the net force on an object with its acceleration along a chosen axis. Often a complex situation is reduced to a set of coupled equations that are then solved algebraically or numerically. For circular motion we decompose acceleration into tangential and radial components, with the radial part pointing towards the centre. Energy methods provide an alternate way to solve problems by tracking kinetic and potential energy and using conservation principles. In classical mechanics we describe motion by specifying position as a function of time and analysing the forces that act on the body. Momentum conservation is especially useful in analysing collisions between two or more bodies in isolated systems. In many examples we idealise surfaces as smooth and strings as light and inextensible in order to simplify the equations. When friction is present the work done by the frictional force converts mechanical energy into internal energy or heat.
